results:
Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about the religious symbolism of the Kwisatz Haderach concept in Polish translations of Dune. Here's what the search revealed:

## Religious Symbolism of Kwisatz Haderach in Polish Dune Translations

The search results provide detailed information about the religious and messianic symbolism of the Kwisatz Haderach concept in Frank Herbert's Dune, specifically regarding Polish translations:

### Kwisatz Haderach as Messianic Figure

The Bene Gesserit called their chosen one "Kwisatz Haderach," a term meaning "prophet-messiah... who could pierce time and space with inner sight."(no content)The name Kwisatz Haderach derives from Hebrew and means "shortening of the path" (Hebrew: קפיצת הדרך).

### Religious Context and Symbolism

The Bene Gesserit conducted complex breeding programs to create Kwisatz Haderach - a being capable of predicting the future and mentally traveling through time and space.(no content)While belief in the coming of a messiah was crucial for both Bene Gesserit and Fremen, they called this savior by different terms. For the Fremen, the messiah prophesied was the mahdi.(no content)According to the plan, this prophet-messiah would be able to look with inner sight into the past, present and future, not only through time, but also space.(no content)The title of the superhuman awaited by Bene Gesserit can be translated as "shortening of the path." Although the Bene Gesserit themselves did not want to call Paul by this name, after drinking the water of life he gained the abilities attributed to Kwisatz Haderach.

### Polish Translation Context

Herbert's Dune appeared in Poland in two translation versions. The first translation was done by Marek Marszał in 1986, over 20 years after the original publication. The second Polish translation was done by Jerzy Łoziński.(no content)Two translations of "Dune" exist on the Polish market, one by Marek Marszał, the second by Jerzy Łoziński (revised editions under the pseudonym Ładysław Jerzyński) and this results in certain terminological differences.

### Messianic Themes and Religious Influences

Frank Herbert, author of the novel on which the film Dune was based, drew abundantly from Greco-Roman and Arab-Islamic culture. In David Lynch's image we can also see various references to the culture, mythology, literature, history, philosophy, military, symbolism, nomenclature, architecture, sculpture or clothing of ancient Greece, Rome, as well as the Arab and Islamic world.(no content)Frank Herbert, creating the Fremen community, was inspired by Islam. But the author's creative invention goes further, he builds various beliefs, introduces the mystical order of Bene Gesserit, to which the mother of the main character belongs, Paul Atryda (later in the book taking the name Paul Muad'Dib), or faith in the arrival of a chosen one called Kwisatz Haderach.

The search results show that the concept of Kwisatz Haderach carries deep religious and messianic symbolism, drawing from Hebrew, Islamic, and other religious traditions, and that this symbolism has been preserved across different Polish translations of Herbert's work.
